authorInfo.title: From the Author
authorInfo.description:
24TTL is a company that specializes in providing innovative solutions for e-commerce, focusing on enhancing the online shopping experience for both retailers and brands. The company is headquartered in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, but operates internationally, including recently expanding to Seoul, South Korea, to tap into the innovative e-commerce market there.

 24TTL is recognized for changing the customer experience in e-commerce and is trusted by Fortune Global 500 companies. They have partnerships with over 400 retailers and marketplaces, focusing on delivering a seamless and omnichannel buying process for online shoppers.

keyTakeaways.title: Key Takeaways
keyTakeaways.description: Successful international expansion requires local entity establishment, deep cultural understanding, systematic business development approach, and long-term commitment. Quick spray-and-pray strategies often fail - sustainable growth comes from building reputation, trust, and genuine local partnerships over time.

emails.subject: The Genesis: From Russia to Dubai - Our First International Leap
emails.body:
**Our international expansion journey began in 2016, not through careful market analysis, but through client relationships.** We were already established as an agency in Russia, working with big businesses and positioning ourselves as 'product and services' - offering **e-commerce design services plus automation scripts**.

**The pivotal moment came when our key client, LG, relocated their manager to Dubai.** They recommended us saying: 'You've been serving us in Russia for five years, and your work is significantly better than what's available locally in Dubai. Let's give it a shot.' **This client relationship became our gateway into the MENA region**.

**From 2016 through 2017, we operated in 'business trip mode'** - fly in, meet clients, get briefs, deliver services. It was essentially the same work we did in Russia: **content management, design, and website support for LG.com**, just for the Dubai region. **The UAE market was far behind Russia in e-commerce maturity**, so we didn't rush into major investments.

**This experience taught us that operating internationally requires local presence.** While we could serve existing clients remotely, real growth only came later when we established local teams and full business development operations.

highlight.title: Client-Driven Market Entry
highlight.description: Sometimes the best market opportunities come through existing client relationships rather than theoretical market analysis - but success requires eventual local establishment

emails.subject: Why Local Entities Matter: From Services to SaaS Across Markets
emails.body:
**When we pivoted from agency services to IT/SaaS business post-2019, everything changed.** The IT foundation enabled scaling - **you can sell the same product multiple times across different markets**, and **it can even work remotely**. This realization drove our European expansion plans.

**We established entities in Netherlands (2020) and later Dubai (2022).** The lesson became clear: **big clients prefer local partners** due to taxes, VAT reclaim, and regulatory compliance. **Cross-country invoicing is messy** - you need local presence for enterprise clients.

**We launched 10 products; only 4 survived.** But those survivors could scale internationally. In Netherlands, we leveraged our partnership with Hatch (later acquired by American company PricePider). **Europe offered higher purchasing power, average order values, and GMV** - but it was also conservative and competitive.

**Post-2022 invasion, Americans said 'We don't work with Russians' and canceled our contract.** We had to pivot fast. **Dubai seemed neutral** - only 1-hour time difference from Russia, open bank accounts, existing infrastructure. This forced move actually opened new opportunities we hadn't considered.

highlight.title: Local Entity Imperative
highlight.description: Enterprise clients require local legal entities for tax efficiency and regulatory compliance - remote operations have fundamental limitations for B2B growth

emails.subject: Market Selection: Why UAE, Mexico, and Indonesia Made Sense
emails.body:
**Post-invasion, we considered multiple markets: U.S., Portugal, Asia, LatAm.** We decided to split efforts across **Mexico, Indonesia, and UAE** to see where traction happened.

**Mexico was chosen as Spanish-speaking LATAM gateway** - my sister Anna co-ran accelerator Hacker Sprint in Chile/Mexico/Brazil and praised Mexico's business climate. I thought it'd be a **U.S. proxy** - I was wrong. **Cultural friction with 'ma√±ana' attitude hurt operations.** Cost: ~$130K, yielded one client.

**Indonesia happened because our Dubai client moved there.** With **270M people and fast-growing e-commerce**, it offered huge potential with low competition. We now have 6 clients (Samsung, Panasonic) but smaller contract values. **We're expanding from Indonesia to Singapore/Malaysia**.

**UAE remained steady since 2016.** Almost no competitors in Dubai compared to Europe. **Netherlands was tied to our Hatch partnership** - logical European base with high e-commerce maturity. But post-acquisition, we pivoted fully to UAE by mid-2022.

**Each market taught us different lessons about competition, culture, and customer behavior.**

highlight.title: Portfolio Approach to Markets
highlight.description: Testing multiple markets simultaneously helps identify where natural traction occurs - but requires significant resources and cultural adaptation for each region

emails.subject: Expensive Lessons: What We Got Wrong in the U.S. Market
emails.body:
**We didn't set budgets or deadlines - decisions were intuitive.** We'd wait for crisis or clear signals to stop. **This lack of systematic approach cost us dearly in the U.S.**

**Our biggest U.S. mistake: thinking 1-2 person teams could work for enterprise sales.** **Breaking into Samsung or LG requires systemic effort** - not something a small team can accomplish. **The U.S. is hyper-competitive** (Salesforce, SAP dominate), and **big brands are nearly impossible to crack without something extraordinary**.

**We can't target SMBs because our tools solve pain points for big brands** managing multichannel inventory (Amazon, eBay, etc.). **SMBs can hire two people to handle this - they don't need our solution.**

**U.S. costs: $50K-$100K** - salaries, travel, exhibits. In 2019, I opened Delaware entity, did roadshow, attended NRF Chicago, hired small biz-dev team. **After a year of significant spend, it went nowhere.**

**The lesson: enterprise sales require extraordinary value propositions and systematic, well-funded approaches.** You can't casually enter the world's most competitive market.

highlight.title: Enterprise Sales Reality Check
highlight.description: Hyper-competitive markets like the U.S. require extraordinary value propositions and systematic approaches - small teams cannot penetrate established enterprise markets

emails.subject: Cultural Nuances: The Hidden Business Killers We Discovered
emails.body:
**Going international means working with different nationalities - cultural nuances can make or break your business.** We learned this the hard way across multiple markets.

**In Mexico and Indonesia, basic feedback like 'You're great guys' means nothing.** **We took politeness as validation** - huge mistake. **Mexicans literally can't say 'no'** directly. There's even YouTube videos on how to say 'yes' properly - if you say 'sim', they instantly know you're foreign.

**We thought three markets would behave like Russian ones.** **We mapped it out mathematically: 300k MRR √ó 20 markets = unicorn!** But **it doesn't work like that without deep integration** - being seen 20+ times at events, knowing everyone, actually living there.

**Hiring costs varied dramatically:** Mexico $4k/month for English speakers, Indonesia $1k, Dubai $2.5k-$3k. **Mexican team was toughest - no feedback tolerance, 'Russian bluntness' backfired.** We saw people playing phone games in Zoom booths.

**Indonesian team: chill but responsible.** Cultural fit matters enormously for team performance and retention.

highlight.title: Cultural Misreading Trap
highlight.description: Politeness is often mistaken for business validation - understanding indirect communication styles and cultural feedback patterns is crucial for accurate market assessment

emails.subject: Fracturing Success: How We Split Teams Across Four Markets
emails.body:
**We had to split the team, mostly by dialogue and logic.** **We fractured into 4 businesses: mature Russia + 3 chaotic startups.** Now it's consolidated as 'Russia + global startup.'

**Business development splits into three functions:** 1) **Contact miners** (LinkedIn scraping), 2) **SDRs** (emails/WhatsApp), 3) **Account executives** (closing). **We tried doing it ourselves, but broken English and local distrust killed us.**

**Team allocation by culture fit:** Gen went to Mexico - he's into football, the culture. **Mexico fit his personality.** Tyoma went to Indonesia - **Bali lifestyle vibed with him.** Cultural alignment matters for leadership effectiveness.

**In Dubai, we hired Syrians, Iranians, Indians** - multicultural team with regional expertise. **Language is everything** - we learned to hire locals through agencies for authentic market penetration.

**Tried lead generation agencies ($5k/month for meetings).** First month: great results. Then: **ghosted across Europe, Mexico, Brazil.** **We copied their playbooks** for process rigor, parsing 200 leads ‚Üí SDR ‚Üí call scripts ‚Üí LinkedIn automation.

highlight.title: Cultural Leadership Matching
highlight.description: Matching leadership personalities with market cultures significantly improves team performance and market penetration - cultural fit affects operational success

emails.subject: Managing Chaos: Lessons from Running Four Markets Simultaneously
emails.body:
**Managing four markets at once was quite difficult.** Gen complained I ignored Mexico (**timezone hell**). Indonesia was easier (+4h). **We had syncs at weird hours** trying to coordinate everything.

**We had a 'Growth Director' overseeing expansion - big mistake: too early to delegate.** Year one, I was barely involved in biz-dev ops. **Reports sounded rosy ('Meetings! Connections!'), but no revenue.** After 1.5 years, we pivoted hard: slashed teams, hyper-focused on deals.

**Our biggest mistakes:**
1) **Spray-and-pray approach cost $2M** but taught us fast
2) **Should've validated first, scaled later** - now we test Korea with 1 FT + 2 interns
3) **Timezone sprawl hurts coordination**

**Surprising win: community-building.** Only Tyoma and I believed in it. **Russia flopped; Indonesia exploded.** Now it's our #1 B2B lever. **Meta-events (IDRF forum) - we underestimated their power.**

**Current priorities:** Dubai #1 (daily presence), Indonesia #2 (timezone advantage), Russia (steady ops), Mexico ('neglected child').

highlight.title: Reputation Before Revenue
highlight.description: Community-building and reputation development often matter more than direct sales efforts - B2B markets require trust and relationship-building over time
